awd_titl_txt: Polypeptoids as model materials for studying the role of monomer sequence and chain shape on block copolymer self-assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1:   NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Polymers that form patterns on the nanometer scale are important components of adhesives and next-generation flexible and rubbery materials.   Being able to control this patterning in next-generation polymers is important for applications such as nanolithography, flexible electronics, and biomedicine. These polymers have much more complicated chemical structures and molecular-scale shapes than typical polymer molecules. This project is targeted at understanding how complexity in the molecule's chemical structure and shape affects its ability to form patterns involving the mutual packing of many molecules.  To do this, molecules will be designed and studied that are inspired by biological polymers (proteins) but allow for tuning of their shape, stiffness, and chemical structure.   Undergraduate and graduate student researchers will be trained at national research user-facilities, participate in local and national scientific meetings, and interact closely with research collaborators. Combining both research and learning to interact in the broader scientific community comprises an integral part of the educational experience for graduate students bound for either industrial careers or the academic world. Furthermore, the PI will partner with the UCSB Center for Science and Engineering Partnerships to incorporate a diverse cadre of incoming community-college transfer students into the research group to both ease transfer shock and provide research experience.   A robust program of "Science Night" outreach activities at Santa Barbara/Goleta elementary and middle schools will continue to generate excitement in STEM fields among a new generation of students.

 
PART 2:   TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Equilibrium self-assembled mesostructures in block copolymers arise from the competition between enthalpic segregation of dissimilar blocks, liquid crystalline interactions, composition, and the mismatch in scaling dimensions between blocks. The ability to synthesize sequence-specific polypeptoids at gram scale presents a unique opportunity to directly test predictions of copolymer self-assembly that suggest both 'blockiness' and gradient strength in a copolymer sequence impacts the chain's ability to minimize free energy by sorting monomers to the preferred side of the interface.   Furthermore, the chain persistence length is tunable on a single chemical platform by controlling the sequence, side chain chirality, and bulkiness.  This platform provides the conformational (persistence length) control necessary to explore the continuum of semiflexible chain shapes between the rod and coil limits. In addition, the fundamental role of asymmetry in contributing long-range entropic effects to the free energy of mixing will be explored.  The goal of this project is to develop a deep understanding of how sequence and chain shape impact the free energy contributions to block copolymer self-assembly. It is expected that this fundamental understanding will guide the design of semiflexible and sequence-defined block copolymers and ultimately impact fields as diverse as organic optoelectronics and biomaterials.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Regents of the University of California at Santa Barbara

por.por_cntn:
Polypeptoids as model materials for studying the role of monomer sequence and chain shape on block copolymer self-assembly

Assembly of polymers into structures with nanometer-scale organization is desirable for a broad range of applications including thermoplastics and patterning agents for lithography. Attaining complex, user-defined morphologies, however, requires moving beyond classical block copolymers to polymers with increased structural complexity, such as precise monomer sequence and polymer chain flexibility.  Over the course of this grant, we leveraged bio-inspired polymers with precise monomer sequence control called polypeptoids to understand the detailed thermodynamics controlling nanometer-scale self-assembly of polymers with non-classical interactions. 

Enthalpic penalties between incompatible polymer segments drive polymers with strong segregation strength, such as polystyrene (nonpolar) coupled to a polar polypeptoid, to form sharp interfaces. We showed that incorporation of nonpolar compatibilizing units into the polypeptoid alters the nature of the interface.1-2 Polypeptoids with identical overall composition adopt sequence-specific differences in chain conformation near the block junction to minimize enthalpic mixing between nonpolar groups and polystyrene.  Because the presence of nearby polar groups suppresses interfacial mixing, distributing the nonpolar groups evenly throughout the polypeptoid results in a softer interface than concentrating the polar groups near the interface. Spreading nonpolar groups throughout the polypeptoid chain leads to chain conformations in which the polypeptoid chains prefer to be near the block junction. In contrast, tapered and inverse sequences extend away from the interface more because the compatibilizing groups are concentrated near the block junction.2 These differences in chain conformation near the interface govern domain spacing and the order−disorder transition temperature when assembled into lamellae.1

Polypeptoid sequence can also be used to define chain shape by controlling side chain chirality and monomer sequence to synthesize either helical or disordered chains, separating the effect of chain stiffness from those of polymer composition. We showed that while helical chains adopt more condensed structures,3 block copolymers in which the polypeptoid portion is helical self-assemble into hexagonally packed cylinders containing larger polypeptoid domains than their unstructured counterparts.4 This is likely a result of packing frustrations increased by stiff helical chains. Chain shape also impacts the thermodynamics of assembly into lamella.5 Specifically, helical chain geometries lead to fewer contacts between neighboring chains and larger chain stretching penalties, thus impacting the balance of enthalpic and entropic free energy contributions. Ultimately, we leveraged these thermodynamic insights to attain more complex geometries, as demonstrated by broadening the double gyroid window using chain shape alone near the polystyrene−polypeptoid interface.6 Combined, these studies model sequence-enabled control of bulk material properties.   

Over the course of this NSF award, we developed rules regarding how copolymer self-assembly can be fine-tuned by compatibilizing the interface between dissimilar blocks and controlling polymer chain shape. This insight is expected to impact applications including elastomers and electrochemical devices and informs the design of synthetic biological structures. Additionally, NSF funding provided support for four successful doctoral theses over the course of the grant: Emily Davidson (Asst. Prof, Princeton University), Scott Danielsen (partial support -- postdoc, Duke University), Anastasia Patterson (DuPont Electronics & Imaging), and Beihang Yu (postdoc, Lawrence Berkeley National Lab). Our laboratory also hosted undergraduate students, 4 of whom were associated with this project, and a local science teacher from the Rivera Ridge School for a summer research immersion. We engage in polymer science and bioinspired polymer outreach activities at local schools including Science Nights at local elementary and middle schools. During the COVID-19 crisis, we adapted these activities to a virtual format. These events included teaching students to build solar cars and developing an at-home experiment about hydrophobic/hydrophilic materials. Finally, to aid in safe school reopening after COVID-19 closures, we taught facilities personnel in the two major school districts in our area, Santa Barbara Unified (15,000 students) and Goleta Union School District (3,500 students), the method published by the Harvard Healthy Buildings Program7 to test air flow in their classrooms. Segalman presented information about the importance of opening windows/doors in naturally ventilated classrooms to the Hope Unified School District and the Santa Barbara County Childcare Council. To reach beyond the Santa Barbara community, Professor Segalman contributed to a report on ventilation in schools and universities.8

 

1.     A. Patterson, et. al. Macromolecules, 2019, 52, 1277-1286.

2.    A. Patterson, et. al. Macromolecules 2020, 53 (9), 3262-3272.

3.    B. Yu, et. al. ACS Macro Lett. 2020, 9 (6), 849-854 

4.     E. C. Davidson, et. al. Macromolecules, 2018, 51 (5), pp 2089-2098. 

5.     B. Yu,et. al. Macromolecules, 2019, 52 (6), 2560-2568. 

6.     B. Yu, et. al. Macromolecules 2021, 54 (12), 5388-5396. 

7.     Joseph Allen, J. S., et. al. 5 Step Guide to Checking Ventilation Rates in Classrooms, <www.ForHealth.org/ventilation-guide/> (2020).

8.     Mcneill, V. F., et. al. Room-Level Ventilation in Schools and Universities. (2021).

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2022
Modified by: Rachel Segalman
